_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Mobil Oil Corporation
Beaumont Refinery
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary

 
1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies

Operations at the ExxonMobil Oil Corporation Beaumont Refinery involve handling, using, processing, and storing hazardous materials that present a degree of risk.  Recognizing these risks, the Beaumont Refinery has an established management system framework called Operations Integrity Management System (OIMS) that sets safety, health, and environmental expectations and manages operating integrity risks.  OIMS addresses all aspect of the business including security measures to prevent unnecessary on-site human exposure and to minimize the potential for any offsite exposure.  The 11 OIMS elements are: 

1. Management, Leadership, Commitment and Accountability
2. Risk Assessment and Management
3. Facilities Design and Construction
4. Information/Documentation
5. Personnel and Training
6. Operations and Maintenance
7. Management of Change
8. Third-Party Services
9. Incident Investigation and Analysis
10. Community Awareness and Emergency Preparedness
11. Operations Integrity Assessment and Improvement

By effectively managing the procedures, technology, and personnel interfaces that produce excellence in our operations, we minimize risks and thus effectively manage and minimize the impact of process related incidents.

The ExxonMobil Oil Corporation Beaumont Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This is evidenced by:

? Our history of support and commitment to the community;
? Our high environmental standards; and 
? Our recognition and certification as a STAR facility in the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration?s (OSHA) Voluntary Protection Program (VPP).


2.  Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The ExxonMobil Oil Corporation Beaumont Refinery, located in Beaumont, Texas, operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products (e.g. jet fuel, die

sel fuel, kerosene, gasoline, LPG, lubricant base stocks and specialty wax) from raw crude oil.  These processes contain regulated flammable substances and flammable mixtures, which may include:  hydrogen, methane, ethane, ethylene, propane, propylene, isobutane, butane, butylene, pentane, and isopentane.  Hydrogen sulfide occurs naturally in the crude oil we process and is present in some refinery processes.  In addition, the refinery uses chlorine for water treatment and ammonia for refrigeration and air emissions control.


3.  General Accidental Release Prevention Program

To ensure that our Risk Management Program is effectively implemented and managed, the Refinery Manager has assigned the role of RMP Coordinator to a staff member with the necessary training, experience, and resources to coordinate implementation of our Risk Management Program.

The Beaumont Refinery has developed programs to comply with the industry?s most stringent environmental, health, and safety standards.  The Beaumont Refinery received the OSHA Voluntary Protection Program STAR Certification in 1996.  The Beaumont Refinery is the largest oil refinery in the U.S. that is STAR certified.  Facilities in the STAR program are required to demonstrate exemplary safety performance and agree to work cooperatively with OSHA to serve as an example for the industry.  OSHA audits these facilities for compliance every 3 to 5 years in order to maintain certification.

Much effort has also been devoted to environmental programs such as waste reduction and emissions minimization.  The Beaumont Refinery voluntarily participated in the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 33/50 Toxic Release Inventory Reduction Program and exceeded the reduction goals set forth in the program.  The Refinery participates in the Texas Clean Industry Recycling program and has developed a partnership with the neighboring Charlton-Pollard residential area to improve the residents' quality of life and strengthen our environmen

tal programs.  These efforts highlight only a few of the programs underway within the Refinery to protect our environment.

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our OIMS elements address each of the essential features of successful accident prevention programs, including:

- Employee participation        -OIMS Element 1, 2, and 5
- Process safety information  -OIMS Element 4
- Process hazard analysis     -OIMS Element 2
- Incident investigation           -OIMS Element 9
- Operating procedures          -OIMS Element 6
- Training                              -OIMS Element 5
- Mechanical integrity            -OIMS Element 6
- Management of change       -OIMS Element 7
- Pre-startup safety review     -OIMS Element 7
- Hot work permit                  -OIMS Element 6
- Contractor safety                -OIMS Element 8
- Compliance audits              -OIMS Element 6 and 11

Our Risk Management Program uses these individual elements to prevent accidental chemical releases.  

In addition to our industry-leading management programs, we have designed state-of-the-art systems and equipment to control, prevent, detect, and mitigate potential accidental releases. 

We employ extensive mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance programs to ensure the integrity of our equipment and safety systems.  Our mechanical integrity program uses equipment surveillance and preventive maintenance activities to identify equipment that may be in need of repair or replacement, before failure occurs.  This program also specifies the repairs (or parts replacement) needed to maintain equipment in acceptable operating condition.

We train our employees to safely perform their assigned tasks.  Our training program includes new employee training as well as periodic refresher training, and training updates when major process or equipment changes are made.  As part of our training, we include provisions for ensuring that employees unde

rstand the covered material, including written tests and field demonstrations.


4. Five Year Accident History

The ExxonMobil Oil Corporation Beaumont Refinery has had three accidental releases of regulated flammable substances from covered processes within the last five (5) years.  One accidental release involved onsite damage to a tank roof, another accidental release resulted in a flash fire injuring three employees, and the last accidental release resulted in offsite environmental damage, specifically, a leak of approximately 5 barrels carried offsite by rain.


5. Emergency Response Program Information

The Beaumont Refinery Emergency Response Program which is outlined and managed under OIMS Element 10 serves as the final line of defense against, and the mechanism for response to, accidental releases and other emergencies.  While the other elements of the Risk Management and Process Safety Management Programs are focused on the prevention of incidents and releases of highly hazardous material, the Emergency Response Plans serve as the guidelines for responding to accidental releases and other emergencies if and when they do occur.

The Beaumont Refinery has an extensive emergency response organization and utilizes state-of-the-art equipment.  Emergency drills and exercises are conducted frequently and coordinated with the Beaumont Fire Department, Sheriff?s Department, Governmental Agencies (TNRCC, Coast Guard, LEPC) local hospitals, and the news media.  Emergency drills, self-inspections, and insurance inspection results provide a continual improvement process to keep plans current and equipment prepared.


6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

At the Beaumont Refinery, we are committed to ensuring a safe and healthy environment for our employees, contractors, and the public.  We plan to maintain the level of commitment and improvement to our environmental, health and safety programs consistent with our past EHS performance by continually improving through sh
